textline.text: POSTDOCTORAL TRAINING
2014-present
EDUCATION
Ph.D.
M.A.
B.A.
Amelia R. Branigan
Cornell Population Center • Cornell University • MVR Hall, Ithaca, New York, 14853
Phone: (917) 439 1682 • Email: amelia.branigan@cornell.edu
(Revised Sept 2015)
Frank H. T. Rhodes Postdoctoral Fellow
Cornell Population Center, Cornell University
for Educational Outcomes
Sociology, Northwestern University
Dissertation: The Social Relevance of Visible Physical Characteristics
I use educational performance outcomes to assess the sociological relevance
of two visible physical characteristics—skin color and body fat— addressing
challenges of accurate measurement and of variation in the salience of these
characteristics across cohorts. I argue that the visible body is itself a social
fact, and that by omitting physical variation from quantitative analysis of
inequality, social scientists render invisible systems of inequality that persist
within categories such as sex and race, seeing only disparities between them.
Through three studies using large national datasets, I demonstrate such
within-sex and within-race variation in educational attainment and
achievement by phenotype, and offer suggestions for better engaging the
visible body in sociological research on inequality.
Committee: Jeremy Freese (chair), Lincoln Quillian,
Sociology, Northwestern University
History and Journalism, New York University, magna cum laude
Quincy Thomas Stewart, Dalton Conley (NYU)
AREAS OF INTEREST
Social Inequality; Education; Health and Illness; Crime and Deviance; Race and Ethnicity
PUBLICATIONS
Branigan, Amelia R., Jeremy Freese, Assaf Patir, Thomas W. McDade, Kiang Liu, and Catarina I. Kiefe.
2013. “Skin Color, Sex, and Educational Attainment in the Post-Civil-Rights Era.” Social Science Research.
Branigan, Amelia R., Kenneth J. McCallum, and Jeremy Freese. 2013. “Variation in the Heritability of
Educational Attainment: An International Meta-Analysis.” Social Forces. 92(1): 109-140. (link)
Freese, Jeremy and Amelia R. Branigan. 2012. “Cognitive Skills and Survey Nonresponse: Evidence from
Two Longitudinal Studies in the United States.” EurAmerica. 42(2): 221-247.

Review.
Branigan, Amelia R. and Jonas Helgertz. “Parental Infertility and Children’s Educational Achievement.” Working
